sect1.title: Interpolation
sect1.para: Most geometrical transformations, such as rotation, scaling or drift compensation utilize or depend on data interpolation. Also some other operations, e.g. profile extraction, work with values between individual pixels and hence include interpolation. As the SPM data are relatively coarsely sampled compared to measured details (full images are typically only a few hundred pixels in width and height), the interpolation method used can become critical for proper quantitative analysis of data properties. Gwyddion implements several interpolation methods [1] and the user can choose which method to use for most of the modules using interpolation.

Here, we describe the principles and properties of one-dimensional interpolation methods. All implemented two-dimensional interpolation methods are separable and thus simply composed of the corresponding one-dimensional methods. The following interpolation method are currently available:

listitem.para:
Linear interpolation is a linear interpolation between the two closest data values. The value
z z
at point of relative position
x x
is obtained as
Linear interpolation formula
z = (1-x)z_0 + xz_1
where
z0 z_0
and
z1 z_1
are values at the preceding and following points, respectively. Its polynomial degree is 1, regularity
C0 C^0
and order 2. It is identical to the second-order B-spline.

Key interpolation (more precisely Key's interpolation with
a = −1/2 a=-1/2
which has the highest interpolation order) makes use also of values in the before-preceding and after-following points
z-1 z_{-1}
and
z2 z_2 , respectively. In other words it has support of length 4, The value is then obtained as
Four-point interpolation weighted sum
z = w_{-1}z_{-1} + w_0z_0 + w_1z_1 + w_2z_2
where
Interpolation weights for Key
\def\Q{\vphantom{(^)_y}} \vcenter{\normalbaselines\ialign{\hfil\bmath#=\Q\emath&\bmath#\Q\emath\hfil\cr w_{-1}&\bigl(-{1\over2} + (1 - {x\over2})x\bigr)x\cr w_0&1 + (-{5\over2} + {2\over2}x)x^2\cr w_1&\bigl({1\over2} + (2 - {3\over2}x)x\bigr)x\cr w_2&(-{1\over2} + {x\over2})x^2\cr }}
are the interpolation weights. Key's interpolation degree is 3, regularity
C1 C^1
and order 3.

Schaum interpolation (more precisely fourth-order Schaum) has also support of length 4. The interpolation weights are
Interpolation weights for Schaum
\def\Q{\vphantom{(^)_y}} \vcenter{\normalbaselines\ialign{\hfil\bmath#=\Q\emath&\bmath#\Q\emath\hfil\cr w_{-1}&-{1\over6}x(x-1)(x-2)\cr w_0&{1\over2}(x^2-1)(x-2)\cr w_1&-{1\over2}x(x+1)(x-2)\cr w_2&{1\over6}x(x^2-1)\cr }}
Its polynomial degree is 3, regularity
C0 C^0
and order 4.

Nearest neighbour approximation is again calculated from the closest four data values but unlike all others it is not piecewise-polynomial. The interpolation weights are
Interpolation weights for NNA
w_k = {{\displaystyle{1\over r_k^4}} \over\sum\limits_{j=-1}^2 {\displaystyle{1\over r_j^4}}}\;,\quad
for
k = -1, 0, 1, 2 k=-1,0,1,2 , where
r-1 = 1 + x r_{-1}=1+x ,
r0 = x r_0=x ,
r1 = 1 − x r_1=1-x ,
r2 = 2 − x r_2=2-x . Its order is 1.

B-spline was misimplemented up to version 2.1 (inclusive) and it blurred data. It should be avoided in these old versions. The weights are
Interpolation weights for B-Spline
\def\Q{\vphantom{(^)_y}} \vcenter{\normalbaselines\ialign{\hfil\bmath#=\Q\emath&\bmath#\Q\emath\hfil\cr w_{-1}&{1\over6}(1-x)^3\cr w_0&{2\over3}-x^2(1-{x\over2})\cr w_1&{1\over6}+{1\over2}x\bigl(1+x(1-x)\bigr)\cr w_2&{1\over6}x^3\cr }}
However, they are not used with directly function values as above, but with interpolation coefficients calculated from function values [1]. Its polynomial degree is 3, regularity
C2 C^2
and order 4.

O-MOMS was misimplemented up to version 2.1 (inclusive) and it blurred data. It should be avoided in these old versions. The weights are
Interpolation weights for O-MOMS
\def\Q{\vphantom{(^)_y}} \vcenter{\normalbaselines\ialign{\hfil\bmath#=\Q\emath&\bmath#\Q\emath\hfil\cr w_{-1}&{4\over21}+\bigl(-{11\over21}+({1\over2}-{x\over6})x\bigr)x\cr w_0&{13\over21}+\bigl({1\over14}+(-1+{x\over2})x\bigr)x\cr w_1&{4\over21}+\bigl({3\over7}+({1\over2}-{x\over2})x\bigr)x\cr w_2&({1\over42}+{1\over6}x^2)x\cr }}
However, they are not used directly with function values as above, but with interpolation coefficients calculated from function values [1]. Its polynomial degree is 3, regularity
C0 C^0
and order 4.
